StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: FusionSeq: a Modular Framework for Finding Gene Fusions by Analyzing Paired-End RNA Sequencing Data
StudyInfo.Description: We have developed FusionSeq to identify fusion transcripts from paired-end RNA-sequencing. FusionSeq includes filters to remove spurious candidate fusions with artifacts such as misalignments or random pairing of transcript fragments and it ranks candidates according to several statistics. It also has a module to identify exact sequences at breakpoint junctions. FusionSeq detected known and novel fusions in a specially sequenced calibration data set, including 8 cancers with and without known rearrangements.

Person.Organization: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIVBRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: Funding support for the development of FusionSeq: a modular framework for finding gene fusions by analyzing Paired-End RNA-Sequencing data was provided by the Prostate Cancer Foundation. Dr.Mark A. Rubin at Weill Cornell Medical College produced data from this study. The research and data was published in the journal Genome Biology: http://genomebiology.com/content/pdf/gb-2010-11-10-r104.pdf. The dbGaP accession assigned to FusionSeq: A Modular Framework for Gene Fusion Discovery with Paired End RNA-Sequencing study is phs000311.v1.p1.

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution did not respond within six months)

ConsentGroup.title: For general medical research, for non-profit only
ConsentGroup.name: PPC
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: A prospective study evaluating Health Related Quality of Life (HRQOL) following Robotic Prostatectomy for the treatment of localized prostate Cancer: Comparison with Open Radical Prostatectomy

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: INSTRUCTIONS: This study has not provided a suggested acknowledgement statement. However, Approved Users are expected to acknowledge the Submitting Investigator(s) who submitted data from the original study to an NIH-designated data repository, the primary funding organization that supported the Submitting Investigator(s), and the NIH-designated data repository (e.g., dbGaP). The acknowledgment statement should include the dbGaP accession number to the specific version of the dataset(s) analyzed.
